pros: People centered place for education and employment.
cons: Unfortunately, the school has now merged.

review_title: Since Northeastern acquisition, terrible internal communication
pros: We have a lot more resources now: salaries are up a bit, dangerous trees are coming down, digital tools widely available.
cons: Internal communication just isn't happening anymore; faculty and staff in Oakland are left clueless to what is going on campus. Even the full academic calendar is inaccessible to most staff. Boston doesn't seem to respect talent or needs on the ground and is very top-down. Continuing Mills students have been given the shaft in many cases because on-campus courses are focused on lower division students, whereas upper division are taught online out of Boston. Presumably this will change with time and regional accreditation. Really hope so.

pros: the connections, network, money, and food
cons: lowpay, difficult administration, not so great food

review_title: Nice campus, but some old ways of thinking
job_title: Faculty Administrative Assistant in Oakland, CA
pros: Beautiful facility, well-meaning work cohorts
cons: Antiquated ways of working, stuck in the past

pros: They encourage professional development of staff, and have a wonderful tight knit community
cons: There are many students who have complex needs, and there is only one of you.

pros: Flexible hours, and remote work available
cons: Unclear supervision, I had many people overseeing my work which got frustrating

job_title: Lead Preschool Teacher in Oakland, CA
pros: Great teachers, amazing families to work with, beautiful, safe campus.
cons: Administration is a nightmare. Beware!

pros: Great coworkers and empathetic supervisors
cons: Low pay. Lots of burn out

pros: Great to work there people were nice and beautiful location
cons: Manager was alright but ended up leaving shortly after I was hired

pros: Colleague are great and supportive
cons: leadership dont care about its people. overworked and underpaid. Will not give out raises, promotions, and cut contributions to retirements.

pros: Flexible great people easy access

pros: Better hours compared to other on campus jobs and flexible with student schedule.
cons: Not very collaborative or many transferable skills for resume building besides customer service.

pros: Has great small classes where your professors really get to know you as a student. Has really great opportunities for undergraduate research.
cons: There are always issues with the financial center.

pros: The staff are very responsive and helpful to each other. Flexible and accommodating workplace.
cons: Poor communication by administration and poor organization leaving staff understaffed, underpaid, and without consistent guidance. Lots of staff turnover.

pros: This was my first experience working in higher ed and I think I've found my calling. Mills is a great community of souls engaged with educational and cultural offerings and engagement. It is an enriching place.
cons: Mills has been running deficits for years and is notorious for cutting into salaries to reduce them. For ten years, the official line has been "no wage increases." You can imagine the revolving door.

pros: Family like work environment in the departments
cons: Too much red tape on the administrative side

review_title: Financial issues makes it a hard place to work

cons:
Low pay

review_title: Amazing community held hostage by underperforming  executives
job_title: Digital Communications Manager in Oakland, CA

cons: The administration, poor executive leadership

pros: The faculty is committed to empowering women, especially women of color. The students are earnest, inspiring, and hard-working.
cons: The College has been in a financial emergency for years, and money is very tight. Even tenured faculty's jobs are at risk.

review_title: Great culture, Poor compensation an benefits
pros: great staff, students, mission, and values
cons: disorganized administration, terrible pay, poor strategic planning

job_title: Art Educator in San Francisco, CA
pros: it's fine its great if you're a student worker
cons: antiquated pay system don't even get me started

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Oakland, CA
pros: They pay on time, even if you submit your timesheet late.
cons: It seems a lot of processes could be done online, through some sort of payment system, instead of having to submit timesheets in person.

review_title: Low morale and neverending work drama
pros: Incredibly welcoming, tightknit, and inclusive environment--you quickly come to know most everyone on campus. Hierarchy exists, but is not nearly as pronounced as other higher ed institutions in my experience. My colleagues became my friends, and were the friendliest, most respectful, and supportive group of people I've ever worked with.
cons: Sadly, Mills is a mess. Severe financial difficulties have killed morale. The turnover has gotten completely insane. Lack of training and a loss of knowledge from long-term employees who have resigned, on top of constant leadership changes, have made the institution completely dysfunctional, making it difficult for Mills to get back on its feet. Salaries are not in line with the high cost of living. Benefits used to be excellent and helped make up for the low salary, but those are constantly being cut and are now below average and no longer an incentive. Staff lack a union and are frequently taken advantage of and asked to do more with no salary increase. Mills would be an outstanding place to work if not for its years of poor leadership destroying the college that unfortunately has continued with the new president. If Mills can ever get it together, you'd be foolish to not want to join the family, but at this point in time, it's a depressing and completely frustrating place to work. :-(

pros: Mills has a truly Beautiful campus. The staff and faculty are good to work with.
cons: Some instability in long term future planing

review_title: mills does not walk the walk
pros: the students allow me the opportunity to see my work in action as I watch them mature and take on the world as they head for graduation, they annually restore my faith, my co-workers are superior human beings who do this work for all the very best of reasons with little praise, long hours, much disrespect and not a great pay scale, I am a director which allows me some freedom in my schedule, close commute
cons: cruel behavior by management, pc gone wild if you are the right group you are in, too top heavy and a president who holds grudges and acts on them, the president has a hard time even saying the word "staff" except at the annual rport session for staff, other than that she will thank faculty and the college officers but not staff, we fear getting sick or having to take time off for prolonged periods because we may be fired

pros: Mills College has a beautiful campus-it is like working in a park. The students are smart, focused and driven. They also come to Mills College looking for a sense of community. The staff at Mills College is wonderful. Mid -management is very supportive of their employees.
cons: There is a lack of professional growth and advancement opportunities for staff. Once you are in a job, you are either in the same position for years or you have to quit (which leads to the very high turnover rate Mills College has).  Comparatively the staff of Mills College is paid lower wages than other universities in the area. Higher management has a habit of promoting themselves, hiring their friends or partners on a regular basis which leads to staff feeling excluded and underappreciated. Staff often feels bitter that we are in the same positions, same salaries (raises are rarely given-just "cost of living raises") and higher management keeps getting promoted. There is alot of favoritism that happens at Mills College.

pros: The students are an inspiration.  If you care about equity and opportunities for women, the mission of Mills College is one you share.  Students, staff, and faculty are very diverse and like it that way.  Mills faculty are talented people with a commitment to social justice and excellence in their fields.  The campus is spectacular.  Despite the economic downturn, new and good things are happening at Mills.
cons: Being in an environment where many employees believe that the highest level of the administration lacks integrity.  Horrendous turnover and high anxiety among the staff due to summary firings.  Watching people arrive at Mills full of enthusiasm and ideas, and wind up angry and detached.  Cynical abuse of donors whose gifts aren't spent as they intended.  Wasted opportunities because of incompetent and irrational decisions under a President who just doesn't understand budgeting and has bloated spending by creating a top-heavy administration loaded with overcompensated yes men.

review_title: Excellent beleaguered faculty and staff serving wonderful students
job_title: Visiting Assistant Professor in Oakland, CA
pros: Mills students are wonderful: idealistic, diverse, appreciative, and motivated.  The faculty are devoted to the students, and the teaching is generally of high quality.  Some professors also have impressive research and publishing records.  The commitment to multiculturalism, women's empowerment, and social justice is real, not window dressing.
cons: While I understand that the administration is constrained by budget concerns -- finally being addressed, rather than covered up, as they were under the previous administration -- they have unnecessarily antagonized faculty by dictating to, rather than working with, us.  They also have treated some long-time staff members badly: For example, when they laid off a popular staff member, they made her leave the building immediately, rather than treating her with respect and providing a transition for the students who depended on her and were devastated by her sudden departure.

pros: I have had the most amazing supervisors and co-workers while working at Mills College. Through both silent and active programs, I have gained knowledge and acquired resources that have become transferrable skills. There is a commitment to social justice at Mills College that has made me not only a better employee, but a better person.
cons: It can be hard to escape the culture of Mills, an almost culture of radical beliefs. I am a firm supporter of the left, but it is not always the best ideology to leave university with and go out into the real world.

review_title: Inspiring team, beautiful location, limited resources
pros: Community, setting, mission, community, brain trust
cons: salary, administrative,  management, high-level communication

review_title: Highly political atmosphere, faculty are undervalued
pros: Mills College is a very special place. It has a central mission and core values that are fantastic if you are interested in feminism, social equality, LGBT issues, first-generation college students, education equity, and the like. The faculty is passionate about their work and the students come to Mills because they want to be there, not because they feel obligated to attend college. Plus, the campus is beautiful!
cons: There is gross lack of transparency in how the College is governed. The faculty are not fairly compensated. Every year we are asked to do more with less.

review_title: Wonderful Staff and Co-workers that care
pros: Mills was a wonderful place to work. My immediate supervisor was kind, caring and I always felt valued. The campus is beautiful! Mills offered fantastic benefits and good work - life balance. I relocated to an other city and have not been able to find the kind of culture I found at Mills. It's a gem!
cons: There were layoffs in 2014 and it's been difficult for some to recover their morale. It's evidenced here by some of these Glassdoor reviews. My experience at Mills was great. Challenging, engaging, focused on educating women.

review_title: Lovely place, great potential, but falling apart
pros: Mills College is a beautiful campus, the students and the faculty are incredibly attentive and active and are committed to social justice.
cons: It feels so unstable at Mills. When I was working there cut-backs were getting a little extreme. I think less than a year after I left my boss was let go and department was taken over by another department.

review_title: Mills College talks big on empowering women but treats female staff like crap.
pros: The students and co-workers are amazing.
cons: All talk about empowering women but treats its employees with disrespect. VP, Deans and above give one another raise after raise after raise, changing job titles in order to explain. The President set a tone where innovation ceases to exist due to fear of ramifications for mistakes. Employees live in fear of losing their jobs. A very anti female place to work.

pros: The environment (physical and social/cultural), the students and faculty, the history. I've had tremendous opportunities to learn new things and grow as a professional.
cons: Work/life balance isn't great considering the lack of opportunity for increased compensation. Morale is low due to a long history of questionable financial decisions by the former administration and the current president taking steps to right the ship.

pros: Students are wonderful; job is interesting; campus is lush and green. If you are committed to your higher education, Mills is a great place to have on your resume.
cons: Adjuncts are overused and paid poorly. Benefits are not always available to part-time professors. Workload is huge, because the college expects a lot of one-on-one interaction between faculty and students.

pros: The students were amazing. Smart, thoughtful people.
cons: Where do I start? The place is in financial ruin. They heap too many jobs on to each staff member. They are hemorrhaging staff like mad and management do not care. There is no accountability for unprofessional behavior, senior staff could verbally abuse other staff with no reprimand, no change in behavior and no repercussions. Likewise, managers (deans) yelled at staff, again, with no change and no repercussions. The salary is abysmal. The benefits are incredibly expensive. If you like doing 7 jobs for part time salary, definitely go work at Mills. Other than that, you can do better.

job_title: Upward Bound Employee in Oakland, CA
pros:
Close knit community 
Decent pay 
Focused on social justice and accessibility

Im an alum and worked at the Trio programs for four years. My students were amazing and my team was dedicated.
cons: Moral seemed to be dropping at the trio programs when I left. We had been dealing with high turnover and internal drama. It was still a great experience and I cherish my time there.

pros: It is a small Liberal Arts College so you have the opportunity to do it all!  Your co-workers become like family.  Help students succeed in their classes and life.
cons: Like everyone else budget woes abound.  The deficit keeps growing and the staff are downsized.  The Adjunct Faculty are now unionized whereas staff are not.  The morale is exceedingly low.

job_title: Academic Program Coordinator in Oakland, CA
pros: After working here for many years I have little supervision and can have a fairly flexible schedule.
cons: Reduced salaries on top of low pay, continued furloughs,  no room for advancement, no support for ever-expanding workloads.

pros: Loved the pleasant but hardworking environment. Expectations for my work were clear, and help was given when asked for. I was trusted to do my job without being micromanaged, which I really appreciated.
cons: The financial situation of the college as a whole was a hindrance as far as upward mobility and raises were concerned.

review_title: A bad new boss ruined the job for me.
pros: Collegiate environment; use of facilities; committed to diversity; interesting staff; slower pace; seasonal workload; nice offices; beautiful campus; quality dining hall;
cons: Oakland location; slower pace leads to lethargy; very hierarchical; committee decisions for every little item; some dead wood on staff

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Hayward, CA
pros: Friendly staff with flexibility and creativity within job parameters
cons: Lack of support on decisions made from faculty.

pros: Beautiful location and grounds, warm, dedicated people everywhere.
cons: Decades of mismanagement has lead to a dire situation. People are leaving in droves due to leadership turnover, compensation stagnancy, and an overall bleak outlook.

pros: Small school where teaching is the priority
cons: Like virtually all other colleges and universities -- way too much reliance on adjunct teachers -- exploiting PhDs to save money.

pros: People were very nice and committed to providing students with a good experience.
cons: Financial situation was crumbly at best, and leadership seemed weak on core factors threatening liberal arts institutions.

pros: Mills College is a beautiful place, with interesting people and lots of possibilities.
cons: However, the pay is low and so is staff morale.

pros: Great people who are driven by, and care about, student success.
cons: Not very well organized though several years of hard leadership and organizational changes have hopefully helped with that.

review_title: I have never worked with more incompetent, complacent people.
